newsitem.title: SOMALIA: Somali bandits hijack WFP food convoy.
newsitem.headline: Somali bandits hijack WFP food convoy.

text.p: Somali gunmen hijacked a World Food Programme (WFP) convoy carrying relief food supplies in north Mogadishu on Sunday, witnesses said.
They said the gunmen, in two "technicals" (armed vehicles), fired warning shots before driving off with two food-carrying trucks to the former Italian Embassy, now a militia base.
The trucks were heading for a military hospital in south Mogadishu when they were attacked.
On Saturday, ten people were killed and six wounded when unidentified gunmen ambushed a truck 60 km (40 miles) south of Mogadishu, witnesses said.
They said the truck, carrying goods and passengers heading for Baidoa town, overturned as the driver tried to escape from the ambush by driving off the road.
Among the dead were a mother and her three children aged between one and eight years.
The attacks came only two days after leaders of the two main Somali factions announced agreement to end hostilities and work for reconciliation in the war-torn country.
Ali Mohammed Mahdi and Hussein Farah Aideed, respectively leaders of the Somali Salvation Alliance and the United Somali Congress, announced their agreement after two days of talks in Cairo.
Somalia has been without an effective government since January 1991 when the government of dictator Mohamed Siad Barre was overthrown.

The south of the country has since been controlled by a number of different armed factions, while the north has declared its secession and independence as the Republic of Somaliland, with its capital in Hargeisa.
